definition: to blockade/to surround/to hem in
to encircle/to surround/all around/to wear by wrapping around (scarf, shawl)
surname Wei
to block up (a road, pipe etc)/to stop up (a hole)/(fig.) (of a person) choked up with anxiety or stress/wall (literary)/(classifier for walls)

sentences.english: Our three players in midfield closed down the spaces well, and it worked perfectly.
sentences.chinese: 我们的三个中场球员围堵得很好，而且做得很成功。

sentences.english: After the meeting, by the Hunan Provincial Party Committee Secretary Zhang Chunxian reporters, "containment."
sentences.chinese: 会后，湖南省委书记张春贤受到记者的“围堵”。

sentences.english: She didn't laugh. Sick of the reporters ambushing me in public toilets, perhaps.
sentences.chinese: 或许我会厌烦记者们将我围堵在洗手间的戏码。

sentences.english: A similar demonstration against Jewish shops took place in Essen yesterday.
sentences.chinese: 昨天在埃森也发生了同样的围堵犹太商场的示威运动。

sentences.english: I remembered black skies, the lightning all around me.
sentences.chinese: 我依然记得漆黑的天穹，狂虐的闪电将我围堵。

sentences.english: Who said of containment against Saddam Hussein We are able to keep arms from him. His military forces have not been rebuilt ?
sentences.chinese: 谁说对萨达姆的围堵政策使得他不能够重建军事力量？

sentences.english: but containment is now the game.
sentences.chinese: 只是现在的策略不再是欢迎，而是围堵。

definition: to besiege/to beleaguer/to attack from all sides/to jointly speak or write against sb
to encircle and annihilate/refers to repeated campaigns of the Guomindang against the communists from 1930 onwards
to blockade/to seal off
surprise attack
to surround/to gird
to fish by casting a net/to capture/to surround and seize
to gang up and beat
to surround/to encircle/to hem in
pincer attack/attack from two or more sides/converging attack/attack on a flank/fork in chess, with one piece making two attacks
to stop/to obstruct
to flock (to see)/to mill/to throng
to drive (vehicle)/to drive out/to chase away/to herd (people towards a gate)
to provoke/provocation
to stop/to obstruct/to bar the way
to run away/to flee in disarray
lit. not one drop can trickle through (idiom); fig. impenetrable (crowd, traffic)
